feed.title: Combined summary - Re: HODL Tax Proposal

entry.title: Combined summary - Re: HODL Tax Proposal
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the concept of introducing demurrage fees on Bitcoin, a topic that has sparked varied opinions among participants. The proposal suggests imposing fees on Bitcoin holders who do not actively use their coins, aiming to provide additional revenue to miners and thereby enhance network security, especially in the wake of reduced rewards post halving events. This idea, however, faces criticism for several reasons.
Critics argue that the proposal shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the Bitcoin protocol and its underlying principles. Key points of contention include the impracticality of self-assigning a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) number without following the established assignment process, which undermines the legitimacy of the proposal. Furthermore, the Bitcoin network's design does not accommodate for tracking "days" or easily deducting balances from addresses, as addresses themselves are not recognized at the protocol level. Additionally, the suggestion that miners contribute proportionally to the computational work of finding a block is incorrect; there is only one winner who solves the block, with all others receiving no reward for their efforts in that round.
Moreover, the critique extends to the legal and jurisdictional naivety of the proposal, noting Bitcoin's indifference to such considerations when designing its system. The mention of Dennis Porter and his perceived authority within this context is dismissed as irrelevant. Critics also highlight the negative tradeoffs of demurrage proposals and the counterproductive nature of centrally planning the price and inactivity period, which contradicts Bitcoin's decentralized market design.
On the other side of the debate, some individuals posit that holders, or HODLers, actually contribute to the network's value by providing scarcity, thereby opposing the notion of taxing property due to inactivity. This perspective emphasizes that the network benefits from the initial acquisition tax paid upon receiving the asset, along with taxes incurred during subsequent sales or transfers, arguing against the need for additional fees based solely on the lack of transactional activity.
